div.p: Greetings. Reverend Father in Christ, I received your letters along with your book, which is addressed to Mr. Zanchi, and the letter to the same; I will take care of it at the first opportunity, although I cannot promise anything certain regarding the time; for that route is now closed due to the plague, which I believe you have understood from Zanchi's letters to me. This evil is also worsening in many places, hence the minister of that church, Hieronymus, has fled to us.
This action in the man displeased me greatly, that he was the first to take flight.

I reproached him; he replied that this is the custom of the Italians, that the churches are immediately closed, and all mutual gatherings of people are prohibited. But because not a few others also followed him, our senate denied them hospitality; they were ordered to return to their own.
Perhaps he has descended to you; he no longer appears here. If he had stayed with his own, he would have been present with advice and action and at least would have administered baptism.
It certainly seems to be a matter of the worst example, and therefore he should not be tolerated, but sent back to his church.

Otherwise, he is a man of perverse mind and intellect. As for you, although the things you announce are mournful, and there is a danger that this evil may spread more widely, yet the things that the Lord sends must be endured.

I easily believe you, that you are beginning to feel nauseated by the vanity of this world and desire to be dissolved and be with Christ; however, your death, no matter how mature, will be too bitter for the church, whenever it finally comes. In the meantime, may the will of the Lord be done.
